title: Why should my authority publish open data?
displayTitle: Why should my authority publish open data?
body: This introductory module examines the benefits of publishing open data for local authorities. Below we will learn about the principles behind open data release, the benefits of publishing and successful case studies of impact in local authorities.

title: The case for publishing open data
displayTitle: The principle behind publishing open data
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Local government has been releasing open data for years on everything from election results to the locations of public toilets. But why should authorities publish open data and what are the best arguements to persuade colleages?
instruction: Click on each of the boxes below to expand.

_items.title: The case for economic benefit
_items.body:
The session explores recent changes in the definition of open data, and allow learners to understand why the current definition has been determined.

The session also examines a number of examples of open data impact from different fields and considers the potential for open data implementation

_items.title: The case for improved services
_items.body: Open data is still a developing field and those working within it will encounter a number of common problems. This sessions presents and clarifys the main challenges before examining the future of open data.

_items.title: The case for transparency
_items.body:
This session begins by looking at how open licences are there to protect data publishers, while also unlocking value. We show how to build a machine readable open license that can be applied to any online content.

The session then continues by looking at the technical, legal, social and practical requirements for making different types of open data usable and some of the most relevant guidelines to support this process.

_items.title: The case for innovation
_items.body: This session will introduce the importance of recent changes around open data modification rules which help combat data errors. We also introduce OpenRefine and how it improves data management by publishers.

title: What is open data?
body:
Open data is usually free at the point of use.

The traditional justification for this free service has been that authorities produce their open data through the operation of taxpayer-funded services.

However, gathering and maintaining data always has a cost attached to it. For this reason, in some cases local authorities may need to charge the user a small fee to cover any costs associated with the data. For this data to qualify as open, the cost should be no more than the 'reasonable reproduction cost' of the data involved. Authorities can charge a fee to cover the costs of supporting a user's data request but should not charge a premium for the data.

title: The benefits of open data release
displayTitle: The benefits of open data release
body: Publishing open data can provide authorities with a range of benefits. Below you can explore the main benefits together with some examples.
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Support growing economies
_items.body:
To support the emergence of new data-driven businesses and the growth of existing ones, authorities are publishing key datasets to support local data economies.

In return, local governments are reaping the benefits of a growing data economy as in Leeds, where the 'Data Mill' platform has attracted more than 250 registered users including new businesses in tourism, schools and waste collection.

_items.title: Improved service delivery
_items.body:
Local authorities need to balance the demands of austerity with the need to tackle small-scale, local issues. In the absense of significant funding for non-frontline services, many authorities are using open data to improve the efficiency of their delivery.

The availability of detailed open data can improve delivery of services at the local level.

One example of this improved service delivery is the tourism initiative implemented by North Somerset council, who used open data to enable the production of a new website supporting the regional tourist economy
Take me to North Somerset case study

_items.title: Cost savings
_items.body:
By growing economies and improving services, open data allows local governments to make savings in key areas, like response to FoI requests and energy use.

In Windsor & Maidenhead council, real-time open data helped reduce energy spending in council buildings by 16%

In Carlisle, publication of real-time business rates has to significantly reduce Freedom of Information requests and is saving the council up to £15000 annually.

_items.title: Better public perception
_items.body:
Authorities have the opportunity to improve their public perception and dialogue through the release of open data.

Open data helps support transparency and also has the potential to increase favourable press coverage through a growing number of data journalists.

Norfolk council is among those improving transparency around procurement processes through the release of
contract pipeline data

title: Case studies of open data impact on local government
displayTitle: Case studies of open data impact on local government
body: Local authorities are already seeing the benefits of publishing open data. The LGA keeps an extenisve collection of case studies that catalogue these impacts. Below are some of the best examples:
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

title: Are you ready for the benefits of open data publishing?
displayTitle: Are you ready for the benefits of open data publishing?
body: Can you recall these four things about the benefits of publishing open data for local authorities?

title: Cost savings from open data
body: Which of the case studies below is NOT a real example of cost savings from open data?

_items.text: Windsor & Maidenhead save 16% on energy consumption in their buildings
Carisle save up to £15000 per year on business rates FoI request
Perthshire increase bus service effiency by 24%

That’s right!

title: Bristol case study
body: What new post did Bristol council create to promote the use of its open data?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Bristol council has created the post of 'intelligent council programme manager' to make the best use of open data and ensure that the public, private and voluntary sectors can make the most of information

title: The benefits of open data publication
displayTitle: The benefits of open data publication
body:
Local authorities can access a range of benefits from publishing open data including cost savings on essential services, creation of local business hubs and better relationships with the public. In our next module we will examine the importance of publishing in consistent ways and how the LGA standards can make publishing simple and maximise results
